review_title: EH - Job says EA but your really a call center agent
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: - Pay w/ over time - Benefits - Remote work/ all tech equipment included
cons: NU is an online school. They are not great with the quality of education. The call cente/EA job is basically selling programs to students who most of time are reluctant. They keep leads that are years old so when you call the student, they are like why are you calling me. NU has discounts and partnerships to make school cheaper for students, that's great and all, but that also has to tell you something about the quality. If I call you and I saw we have a discount for you that is kind of strange. In my mind. I personally have my BA and getting my masters both from state schools, neither have discounts, but lots of other ways to make education cheaper. You have goals of about 10-15 admits a month. Heavy for someone who is not good at sales. They push you on dials no matter what your talk time is. It is a call center. Good Luck! OH BTW my former director and manager was a former collections agent. That should tell you something...

review_title: Look at the surge in bad reviews (Management is reverse King Midas)
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: I got my Master's degree almost totally paid for. That really was about the best thing this place offers. It is remote, which was nice, but that's it. I loved the people I worked with.
cons: Here is what happened to me after being there for 3 years in two different positions and NEVER missing goals. I woke up to clock in and saw an alert on my Workday dashboard read, "Benefits have been redacted." I alerted my team, and everyone in my department had the same alert. This is a bad sign for those who have never been through something like this. The team started to throw rumors around, and then we asked the department above us if they all had the same alerts. In short, they did. Before we could even ask management what was happening, we all got an email that we were scheduled for a meeting in the next half hour. My manager, team, adjacent team, and team above us were all being let go that day. (around 40-50 people) You might not think anything is wrong with this situation at first glance. I fully understand that businesses make tough business decisions, and sometimes means, cuts must be made. However, they did not intend to release all these people in one day. They had leaked the layoffs via our timecards showing they took away our benefits when they did not mean to. They also stated several times there would not be any layoffs and that changes were coming but nothing to worry about. This is one of about 6 massive fumbles management has made in the past 3 months, from 401ks being terminated and moved to not giving raises despite evaluations and other things that did not make any sense. In short, the management is the reverse of King Midas. They turn everything into a disaster that they touch. These people with Master's and Doctorate degrees in Organizational Communication couldn't even conduct a professional layoff. Let that sink in; these educated people who have been moved around different universities all still have the same positions with consistently high-paying salaries. The bottom line is it's all a dog and pony show. The managers constantly move from university to university, making huge mistakes, tanking one university and moving to another.

job_title: Academic and Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
- Education benefit, free tuition to NUS schools
- Work from Home
- Therapy benefit
cons:
- Company is in the middle of a large transition, with no end in sight and no real plan to bring it to an end.
- Zero support or interaction with upper-level management. 
- Extremely High Turnover, no real plans to reduce it despite being pressed in company meetings to address it. 
- Too many requirements to meet, you feel forced to work late or be the target of students and leadership. 
- Entitled students regularly harass you over their money. Regular target of screaming and yelling over financial aid. 
- Compensation does not increase more than once a year, no performance-based increases. 
- No reason to stay, no real incentive to work there additional years. 
- Bad technology to work with, constant crashes and slow databases. 
- Performing the work of several roles, only compensated for one.
- They provide therapy now, for the anxiety you will feel after dealing with the aggressive students. 
- Zero roadmap to reduce turnover or even identify and address key pain points
- Training was inadequate, did not prepare advisors for the role. 
- Company invests heavily in bringing in new students, but not support for existing ones. There are 5-6 people working to bring new students in, but only 1 supporting them post-enrollment.

*laid off all full-time faculty. There is no chance to advance beyond part-time status and no one to mentor or take leadership in curriculum.
*Stopped paying a salary per course and now makes faculty enter hours on a timesheet for an hourly wage as if we're unskilled workers

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: I can truthfully say that academic leadership (along with a select few members of operations leadership) at Northcentral University cares about its students, faculty and team members. From an academic standpoint, the University has grown exponentially over the last few years and those that have led NCU through this growth deserve the highest praise. Throughout my tenure, I had the great fortune of working with a few of these leaders, whose advice and guidance I will be forever grateful for. Thanks in no small part to these select few, I was fortunate enough to have enhanced my career at NCU.
cons: Unfortunately, what began as the opportunity for personal and professional growth turned in to discouragement, frustration and disappointment. And what was formerly a self-motivated and dedicated team of individuals has deteriorated in to a shell of the team I once knew - both literally and figuratively. Personally, I experienced a tripling of my workload due to the departure (both voluntary and involuntary) of and refusal to backfill almost 50% of the team I joined just 2.5 years prior, within a matter of months. It was not just myself that shouldered the burden of this reduction in workforce, and as one can imagine this has led to a morale free-fall, an irreparable lack of trust in leadership, and an overall sense of urgency to depart before the chopping block forces you to do so. It saddens me to have to say it, but the students, alumni, faculty, and University as a whole will all soon suffer for this new leadership's self-centered managerial style.

review_title: Low Pay, Great Benefits; Better Than Competition
job_title: Admissions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA

Having worked for two other schools of this type (Trident University and ITT Technical Institute), I can honestly say this is the best of the bunch.  While they also stress enrolling students, it's not the only function of the job, and they do not force a "Glengarry Glen Ross" sales culture on you.  Degrees are also regionally accredited, so you can enroll students in good conscience.  Their health plan is Cadillac - you will never have to worry about your health if you choose their PPO, and starting work later in the day is a blessing.
cons: WAY overworked and underpaid; leadership is nuts in Los Angeles.  Think they know more than they do, form opinions and stick to them - if they like you, it takes a lot for them not to; if they don't, nothing you do will change their mind, and the basis for that is pretty arbitrary.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Free bachelors degree when full time after the six month grace period which is about $63,000 in savings. Easy to move around to different departments to gain different experiences. Health insurance is very cheap and decent company match on 403 b.
cons: They pay is terrible wherever you go unless you're working as the chancellor. Speaking of the chancellor he's running the place like a for profit institution and is only concerned about getting students enrolled but can't figure out how to make them stay. The financial aid undergraduate students receive is a joke and a lot of students will take out private loans just to get through their first year. The chancellor is currently preaching about the "exceptional student experience" and staff if unable to do so do to the high turnover rate within the Office of the Registrar due to low wages and no formal trainings provided.

job_title: Dissertation Chair in Prescott Valley, AZ
pros: The benefits include the ability to work remotely and the pay is not bad.
cons: The worst university I have worked for, and I have worked for four brick-and-mortars and one other online university. The leadership is comprised essentially of lawyers whose sole mission is to increase profits. Faculty members have absolutely no voice (NCU was forced to create a faculty senate, but only for accreditation - it has no power and was designed that way). If a faculty member voices skepticism or does not agree with leadership, leadership looks for (or invents) cause for termination. Faculty member conversations using their assigned 800 numbers are monitored surreptitiously. Their game is essentially this: students are rubber-stamped through their general and research coursework, often with a 4.0 GPA (which is meaningless) - this is where they make their money - and then they attempt to backstop the process with an Academic Success Center. Students arrive to their Dissertation Chair never having received real feedback or being held to any standard and almost all are completely unprepared to conduct doctoral level dissertation research. Students then have three courses to complete a component of the dissertation or they are dismissed. If you have ethical standards and believe in academic integrity and rigor, think twice about NCU - I wish I had.

review_title: Archaic thinking and bullying is the norm...

A common phrase in the company is "thrown under the bus".  That should give any applicant an idea of how management and co-workers treat one another in the company.  There are many poor performers who have protection of the top executives and others must pick up the slack.  Staff employees are paid as if it was the 1980's and rarely are recognized for significant contributions. 

Another funny iniative that the management is forcing on the employees is to have "PRIDE" for the company.  The sense of pride is a feeling that is from the employee's satisfaction of the job and company's activities.

review_title: Very high turnover. Need I say more.

review_title: We can still save this place!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: A great place to build a resume and gain experience in higher education. Good tuition, medical, dental, retirement benefits, etc. The heart of this institution, its seasoned and student-focused staff, is what keeps this University standing. Education is an excellent product - there are not many jobs where you're able to help people improve their opportunities, income, quality of life for themselves and their families. The opportunity to positively impact lives is amazing!
cons:
Within the last 3 years, the University has experienced various breakdowns, and this has been at the expense of its students and staff. Communication is at an all-time low. 

I’ve been with National for nearly a decade. Why the loyalty and why the investment? I care about this institution; I care for its students. I care about its staff, who bend over backwards to salvage the SICs we still have. But these SICs are slowly being eaten away by broken Registrar processes, arbitrary SHHS decisions, Regents’ inability to fund various degree requirements coupled with the recent, secretive tuition hikes two months sooner than is typical - education is now fiscally out of reach for all undergraduates without grants or private loans. Monetary decisions are made rashly and with little thought of unintended consequence - lack of collaboration with departments prior to high level decision making is to blame.

job_title: Academic Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Undergrad degree paid in full, discounted rate (based on taxes) for a grad program. Paid holidays and given sick and vacation time, benefits were given right away.
cons: This is a non-profit university (explains the pay/salary) with a for-profit attitude (ask all the upper-management what institutions they have worked at). All employees at this university are underpaid for their services, especially if you work in the Admissions department. Last year the Chancellor addressed that the reason why we couldn't get higher merit (raises) was because he blamed the low enrollment numbers (indirectly blaming the Admissions Advisors). As an Admissions Advisor, you are expected to recruit new students and retain your current students and you are the only advocate for the student. Every month you have enrollment goals (although your pay is not dependent on the enrollment numbers). Upper management relies on reports that aren't accurately updated due to overwhelmed advisors. Each advisor has a work load of about 150+ students (if you're lucky) to about 350+ (if you've been there for a long time). The higher ups require that you always speak to your students by phone and always follow-up with an e-mail. The university trains you to guide the students from beginning to end. And by guide, I mean that as their advisor, it is your responsibility to remind students that they have to buy their textbook for first class, submit missing documents for Financial Aid to their Financial Aid advisor, submit transcripts for evaluation even though you've told them three times since they've enrolled... It gets even worse when the university cancels courses without explanation to the student but you're left explaining to a student why his or her degree is delayed. When students are on Academic Probation or Disqualification, it is the advisor's responsibility to call the student to inform them and advise them of their next steps. The university sends out systematic messages to our students but advisors STILL have to follow-up. There is no support---physically or emotionally. You'll always talk to management (your immediate supervisor) but nothing gets done. There is absolutely no open communication between departments, but you will be lucky if you can make a friend with someone who isn't from your department.

job_title: Finance and Academic Advisor in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: I have been a finance advisor for a few years now. I like having knowledge of both roles so I can better advise my students. The reason I have stayed with NCU for so long is that it feels like a family. I feel like I can go to my manager or lead and they will always listen and try to help me and I've always loved my coworkers here. Let’s tell it like it is, the few that are upset about this transition are the ones that never used to have to put in a full day's work to get their job done. This is what we are here for!  Was the transition perfect? Of course not. But I think what made it the hardest was people not being open to change and having a poor attitude. Learning a new job is hard but it's all about your attitude. The team is already getting better at the combined role. I think that morale is going up now that the training part is over and I'm really proud of us, actually. The good ones will stick through the learning phase and will come out stronger.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits-dental, vision, health, PTO, sick leave, tuition waiver if you're just looking for any degree, retirement fund matching
cons:
no professional development opportunities/mentorship
poorly prepared leadership
no accountability for some employees while others are held to high standards
high turnover rate 
resistance to change 
low morale

It pains me to leave a seemingly scathing review because I was once a happy, motivated NU employee. The NU leadership team wants to deliver an exceptional student experience, however, they fail to realize that goes hand in hand with an exceptional employee experience. Employees are the lifeblood of organizations. The professed values of the university are quality, innovation, collaboration, diversity, and access. Let’s look at these from a minions perspective. 

Quality- The fact the university is regionally accredited continues to puzzle me. How low is the bar? My conclusion after enrolling in graduate courses and seeing all the administrative dirty laundry-VERY LOW. 

Innovation- Minimal to no training is provided on how to efficiently use new software and student database management system. Training and reference materials consist of outdated word documents stored in different locations. We have Sharepoint but management does not see the benefit of actually using it to collaborate.

Collaboration- Pfft. Company culture is The Hunger Games- corporate version. Policies and procedures change willy-nilly and there is no transparency. 

Diversity- I’ll give them that one. 

Access- It’s not for those who are NU employees AND students. Flexible scheduling is a benefit some staff members enjoy while others are denied the same benefit without a valid reason. Perhaps its their way of preventing staff from successfully using their tuition waiver. Maybe they enjoy the thought of employees sitting in soul-crushing commutes. Brings that 9 to 5 song by Dolly Parton to mind.    

Like many of my colleagues, I no longer volunteer as tribute.

review_title: Comparable to an Ira Levin Novel
job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Scottsdale, AZ
pros:
Strives to provide a challenging education product and is definitely not a diploma mill. 

Those recognized as having talent will go far and in a short amount of time.

Genuinely looks to offer an energetic, positive environment for its employees (unless you are in Prescott Valley).
cons:
The dissertation process is a mess. It got to the point I began to feel like it was a scam on the students. These students are paying THOUSANDS and are often carrying a mortgage worth of debt, and I would hear horror stories about dissertation chairs flip flopping on them, failing to realize their concept was for a Ph.D. and had been looking at it as doctoral... The enrollment process is a bit deceptive as it glosses over the process. 

Student services (enrollment, finance, and academics) is always having their wheels reinvented. Down to seating assignments. Change is good, but not when an organization moves to one mode only to switch back to the way things were done 5 seating charts before. 

Though talent is recognized, it also leads to favoritism. Top performers get slapped on the wrist for behavior that has potential for lawsuits. 

The positive vibes and all that jazz is great when it's organic. But it's policed so ridiculously that if people do anything that can be called into question, they are pulled into an office discussion. Feels like the town of Stepford.

job_title: Anonymous in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Benefits and pay are above average.   Everybody I have talked to is making more than their last job and benefits are on par or better.   Supervisors don't ride you too hard and there's fun events pretty often.
cons: Constant change.   This can be a pro too though.   There's also a good old boys' club feel to the leadership team and we're not sure what some of them do.   They have cleaned out a lot of poor leaders recently tho.

review_title: Meh... have had worse jobs and better ones
job_title: Admissions in San Diego, CA
pros:
I like most of the people I work with.
flexible time off  depending on manager
decent pay for an office job
basic benefits
we may get raises this year even though sales has been flat out of the "gracious kindness" of the board of trustees
staff scholarship
cons:
the caliber of students is under par. They pretty much admit any one and in turn these are the "customers" that you deal with every day. Many are entitled and think that they pay a lot for school they deserve to be in easy classes.  dealing with many complaints from students everyday regarding various different parts of the university.
 It is all run by a "good ol boy" club from San Diego. 
Raised cost of benefits this year and blamed the admissions team that they cannot afford to cover benefits, but spent millions on advertising and hosting the holiday bowl. That we saw no leads and only focused on the San Diego region and then ride other locations to meet numbers.
Lack of support if you are not in the San Diego region
claims to be  a "non-profit" but runs like a for profit. lots of sales training... wait I am sorry not "sales" training, focusing on "student service".
 focuses on numbers way too much student service falls by the side. not clear communication better departments or stream lining an admission process for each students. 
lots of blame placed on the admissions team. 
Leads seem to not be a valid as they use to be. It almost seems that they are buying peoples' information from those marketing companies that sale consumer info. There have been many calls made where the caller has no idea how we got their information and why we would be calling about school. 
If there are not valid leads then how are we suppose to make the "numbers". 
Marketing department focuses only on the San Diego region other regions are out on their own. 
Changes that are now being implemented. We need to keep logs on calls and appointments. reading from scripts for new student calls- seems to be going into more of a sales mode.
 unclear expectations/changes every day.
Be prepared to not be an advisor, but a sales person. At least I can take these skills and maybe sale used cars in the future.
management training is a joke. 
locations out of state are closing and making people uneasy if other locations are going to close in the future. feels like they are trying to find where to cut people and what locations based on productivity. 
software system is outdated, but a new one may be on the way
lack of  job growth outside of San Diego. 
employee morale is falling everyday. 
When you say where you work people already assume you are a sales person and work for "one of those schools". 
Other departments in San Diego not responding or long turn around time of requests for things. 
Reputation is not good with people. not held in prestige even with community colleges. There is no student culture or something for students to hold on to. Like other schools people are proud to be a bruin or something. 
Over priced for our students
low pay compared to other advisor positions out there.
may get a 1.7% -ish raise this year- WAL-MART employees get larger raises a year for good merit!!! 
high turn over-managements does not even get mad when you move on because they know it is for the better.  \
Yes, we should be grateful we have a job and even got a raise, but you add more work and raise benefits and want employees to be happy. Most will not even see the raise and make less then last year because the cost of benefits.   When you see the wasted money all over the place (like the holiday bowl) that is not helping to grow the business and the cost of one thing can be used to pay for all of the rise in benefits, it is sickening. 
I feel like it is a PR gimmick to make the company look better than it is because they can say they gave their employees raises even though sales has been down. It makes the company look better of financially then it is. We used to get these articles about how the company is doing and assets.. haven't seen that this year? hmm...
 I wonder what the chancellor/president makes? yes that is right the Chancellor and President are the same person... like seriously??

Not a bad place to start or try to get some education paid for, but do not plan to stay long after. It will suck your soul dry and leave you with no hope for humanity based on the caliber of students that are being turned out of here.

review_title: Learn all you can and then move on!

review_title: Great place to start a career and develop skills

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
This is a good position to gain experience in higher education administration right after college. The coworkers are great to work with and the upper management gives great support. You learn a lot as far as higher education policies, procedures, and operations. Not a hostile environment at all and you can still have a good work/life balance.

You can enroll to one bachelors with no tuition cost and one masters, but you'll have to pay taxes on which is no big deal. 403b Matching percentage rate is decent (but general pay is weak).
cons:
With such a good work environment in an office setting, unfortunately the pay is below par which is a bummer because you have really good young and professional employees who are looking for a career. Turn over rate is terrible.

Job postings are ridiculous. Positions requires bachelors degree and with 2+ years of higher education experience and the pay starts at $12 bucks. You can make more at an in-n-out with no degree and experience!

They hire just about anyone for Academic Advisors who are completely not eligible to advise anyone, but they stay because for some reason they have good job security. If you can't do your job correctly especially when you keep making the same mistakes and misguiding students- you should be let go. Hire educated people.

review_title: Shame on me ? Shame on you.
job_title: Student Services in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Co workers, students, tuition benefits flexibility
cons: There are people who post on here and give more than one star reviews to compensate for the negative reviews. You can tell who those people are. The truth of the matter is there have been lay offs and it felt horrible to see co workers/family let go at a moments notice. To be at work wondering if you could be next because of the number of years you have dedicated to the university was so stressful. I felt sick most days. I’m still nervous wondering what day will be “my” day. I don’t think there are wacky and crazy people posting on here like someone else mentioned. I understand that as a university there will be change from time to time, but there’s a way of going about that change what happened last week was wrong in many ways. I hope this was the only round of lay offs and campus closures, unfortunately when it comes to the almighty dollar I’m sure this is just the beginning.

job_title: Specialist in San Diego, CA

job_title: Admissions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Free Education after working for 6 months. 
Paid vacation and sick days.
cons:
-By the time I was able to receive the benefits of free education (I enrolled into an MBA program), I had lost faith in the quality of the education. The accelerated month long courses, is too fast for the majority of students. I started feeling guilty "selling" the school to others, when I was not impressed with my own program.
- This was my first real job out of college, so the salary I was earning at the time felt like it was a lot. Looking back, I realize how low the pay is for the amount of work you put into the job.
- Management looks after themselves, causing high turnover of advisors. The staff that worked the year before I was hired on, they all quit at the same time. I should've seen that as a red flag. My coworkers and I all started at the same time, and wouldn't you know, we all quit one year later at the same time. My manager hardly came into the office to help us with our enrollment goals. Anytime we under-performed, we were thrown under the bus, even though we made so much effort. We had no budget for marketing, etc.
- If you work at an Online Information Center location that is in a mall setting, you better expect to work crappy mall hours. We had to work the crazy extended mall hours during the holidays. Most days, each of us would be the only employee working in the office and our shifts would barely overlap by 30 minutes. We would have to hold our bathroom breaks till the next person came in.

review_title: Don't waste your time, look elsewhere
job_title: Admissions Advisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Tuition discount, for those pursuing a Bachelor's/Master's degree, Health benefits. A clean, working atmosphere. Co workers are friendly and helpful.
cons: Starting pay is very insulting. The school will use all the excuses in the world to not give employees their raise. Upper management does not listen to employees. The school is run like a for-profit school where the focus is on calling people everyday to beg  them to enroll. As an admissions advisor, you will spend the majority of your time reminding the same students  every week to submit missing transcripts or to pay the collections hold on their account just because a lot of the people who apply to the University are irresponsible and do not take the school seriously as  anyone can get in with a 2.0 GPA for undergrad and 2.5 GPA . So you don't have to be a rocket scientist to attend school here. You will also find National University in malls, so if you get hired to work at a center in the mall, you will be required to wear a uniform, work both Saturday and Sundays and work until 9pm. The schedule changes every week so if you want your life to revolve around work and you want to struggle to pay your bills for the rest of your life doing the same job since there is no room for growth , than work for NU.  They actually beg employees to stay that are looking for better paying jobs elsewhere because they know nobody else will stoop low enough to except such a low paying job even when they have been unemployed for 2 years!
